reviewText: "Sherlock" is an update of Sherlock Holmes created by Mark Gatiss and Stephen Moffat, both "Dr. Who" writers, that places the detective in contemporary times. Like the Holmes of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's creation, this Sherlock is fascinated by science, deduction, and keeps up with the latest technologies. In Moffat's words, "He's not meant to be a relic of a bygone era. He's meant to be ahead of everybody else in the room." He runs a web site called "The Science of Deduction". He keeps ongoing, rather gruesome, experiments in his fridge. He carries a cell phone. And, like Conan Doyle's Holmes, he knows and cares little about politics or popular culture.The first episode of the series, "A Study in Pink", takes inspiration from the novel that introduced Sherlock Holmes to readers in 1887, "A Study in Scarlet", right down to Dr. Watson's origins and the clue left by the murder victim. The new Dr. John Watson (Martin Freeman) is a veteran of the war in Afghanistan, just as the 19th century's Dr. Watson was a veteran of the Anglo-Afghan War. He is looking for a flat while Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch) is looking for a flatmate. As for Holmes' character, the writers seem to have taken bits from Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes and modernized them. Instead of smoking a pipe, Sherlock wears a nicotine patch(es), for example.Instead of simply being aloof, "Sherlock"'s writers have gone a step further and made Holmes a self-described "high-functioning sociopath". Although Sherlock is clearly thrilled at the prospect of a bloody crime spree in London, he's not really a sociopath. He just doesn't bother to hide his disinterest in people. He may fall somewhere on the shallow end of the autism spectrum, which is very 21st century indeed. But if Holmes were really a sociopath, he would be repulsive, so I'm not sure why the writers want to imply that he is. Then there is his brother Mycroft (Mark Gatiss), who is some sort of high-ranking intelligence officer and puppeteer. He seems more the sociopath.Perhaps inspired by ongoing speculation on the part of Conan Doyle fans regarding the detective's lack of interest in women, "Sherlock"'s creators have chosen to make an issue of it. It's not clear whether the writers intend to imply that Sherlock is gay or only that his acquaintances assume he is. But the main effect of this ambiguity is to create humorous situations when everyone assumes the same of Dr. Watson. Humor is one of this series' strengths. I wasn't sure what to make of it at first, but the humor and fast pacing got me. Not the stories. "Sherlock" shares with most modern mysteries impossible plots and motive-less crimes. Those are its flaws. The three 90-minute episodes are:"A Study in Pink" introduces us to the new Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson with a serial killer case. Over a period of several months, three Londoners have died in unexpected suicides, all by taking the same poison pills. Foul play is suspected, and Detective Inspector Lestrade (Rupert Graves) is feeling pressure to solve the case. John Watson is an army doctor, veteran of the Afghan War, looking for a flatmate. He's introduced to an eccentric misanthrope, Sherlock Holmes, by an mutual acquaintance. Holmes is a "consulting detective" with amazing powers of deduction to whom Lestrad has reluctantly turned for help with this baffling case. His new flatmate Dr. Watson is sucked into the drama and is able to contribute his medical and military expertise."The Blind Banker" finds Dr. Watson looking for a job, as his bills pile up. An old acquaintance asks Sherlock to investigate a break-in at a bank. The intruder spray-painted yellow graffiti on a wall, but no one could figure out how he got into the building. When one of the bank's traders is found dead in his apartment shortly after returning from a trip to China, and there is another death under similar circumstances, the trail leads Holmes and Watson to an underground Chinese crime syndicate called the Black Lotus. But the new police detective on the job, DI Dimmock (Paul Chequer), is doubtful of Holmes' conclusions. And an expert in Chinese antiquities, Miss Soo Lin Yao (Gemma Chan), who might be able to help the investigation, has gone into hiding.Holmes and Dr. Watson aren't getting along so well in "The Great Game". And just as Holmes laments the lack of interesting cases, his block explodes. A mad bomber is playing a sadistic game that keeps the Holmes, Watson and DI Lestrade on the edge of their seats. The bomber gives Holmes a series of cases to solve, each time strapping a bomb to a hostage and allowing a number of hours to solve the mystery. If Holmes isn't quick enough, the bomb will explode. Holmes suspects the mind behind the bombs might be that of his rumored arch-rival, Moriarty. Meanwhile, Holmes' brother Mycroft is pestering him to track down a memory stick containing some documents vital to national security that went missing when a clerk at MI6 died.The DVDs (BBC/Warner 2010): Disc 1 contains "A Study in Pink", "The Blind Banker", and an audio commentary for "A Study in Pink" by producers Sue Vertue, Mark Gatiss, and Stephen Moffat, who also wrote this episode. They discuss the genesis of the series, finding modern equivalents, allusions to Conan Doyle's story, differences from the pilot, cast, characters, locations, sets. Disc 2 contains "The Great Game" and "Unlocking Sherlock" (32 min), a featurette that addresses modernizing Holmes, casting, shooting in London, the score, and the Watson/Holmes relationship. The 60-minute pilot episode that never aired on TV is also on Disc 2. It's a shorter version of "A Study in Pink". It has lower production values but lacks extravagant filler, so the mystery is more plausible and writing tighter. I prefer the pilot to the feature-length version. It's evident that all of the episodes would have benefited from the shorter format. Subtitles are available in English.
summary: Fairly Meticulous Update of Sherlock Holmes with Humor & Fast Pacing but Bad Plots.

reviewText: Since the first books of Sherlock Holmes came out decades ago, the iconic character has gotten both either small screen or big screen at least once a year.  Most of these were small items produced in the UK for the British audience.  Then Robert Downey Jr. teamed up with Guy Ritchie to give Sherlock a full-blown treatment loaded with special effects.  However, the reviews of that film were mediocre as many complained about the excess of action at the expense of mystery, suspense and deliberative storytelling.  Leave it up to BBC to counter with an awesome 3-part miniseries.  Coming out at the end of 2010 for the US audience, each episode clocks in at over one hour in length; commercial free.  The episodes are set in modern-day London, with original backgrounds for all the main characters.  Watson is a veteran of the Afghan War, Mycroft works for British intelligence, and Moriarty poses as a gay man to get to Holmes.  The crimes themselves are wonderful plot devices and each episode is actually a convolution of multiple plot lines that weave in and out until they join at a great climax.  Overall, I would call this the best miniseries of all of 2010.

reviewText: I just want to thank Amazon's Prime Instant Video for once again providing me access with a new favorite BBC show that I will plan on watching in the future.Being a fan of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's it was with great pleasure to see this update to the consulting detective. Fans of Steven Moffat (Coupling and Dr. Who) will definitely want to tune in to see how he has updated one of the most famous detectives in literary times (next to Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple).The new television series stars Benedict Cumberbatch as Sherlock Holmes and Martin Freeman as Doctor John Watson.For fans of the Sherlock Holmes novels many of you should be familiar withA Study in Scarletsince that was the first novel by Doyle that introduced the characters of Sherlock Holmes to Dr. John Watson. This new series keeps elements of "A Study in Scarlet" intact such as Holmes and Watson meeting for the first time. However, there are updates due to the technology of the day.We have Holmes and Watson meeting once again through a mutual friend and agreeing to move in together at 221 B Baker Street.Due to inexplicable suicides DI Greg Lestrade played by Rupert Graves, consults with Holmes in order to determine out a perpetrator in these crimes. Unlike the atagonism that was between Lestrade and Holmes in the novels, in this television update, Lestrade uses Holmes in order to solve tough and baffling cases. And at one point says to Watson, "Sherlock Holmes is a great man. I hope one day that he can be a good man."This is episode 1 of series 1 and runs 90 minutes. I would recommend that you plan on hitting pause if you leave the room for very long since watching Holmes break down a puzzle or being able to determine so much about a person in 30 seconds is awe inspiring to watch and see.We get introduced to Holmes older brother Mycroft Holmes and for the first time hear the name, "Moriarity".  What is great to see is the developing friendship between Holmes and Watson. We have several running gags between Holmes and Watson's living arrangements with everyone thinking they are a couple and with Watson's outright admiration of Holmes intellect. There were several laugh out loud moments for me (when Holmes tells Watson to think it through next time someone offers him a bribe, they could have split it, being just one for me).The show often helps a viewer out by showing what text messages say or show you what Holmes is seeing when he looks at someone.I was able to view this episode for free through the Amazon Prime Program.Definitely recommend watching!

reviewText: Sherlock Holmes in the 21st Century. This BBC Series (made in conjunction with the Masterpiece folks) has only three episodes, plus the pilot (which is a shorter and slightly different version of the first episode, "A Study in Pink".I've always been a big fan of Sherlock Holmes, going all the way back to the stories by Sir Aurthur Conan Doyle. When I watched this series, I was thrilled. Not only had the BBC managed to successfully transport the famous detective all the way to the 21st century with all its electronic wizardry, but they managed to capture his personality, as well. Holmes is basically bored with life and wants nothing more than a challenging case to solve. John Watson is a war veteran (returned from a stint in Afghanistan, where he was wounded) who is now living on a military pension. A mutual friend introduces the two in the first story, A Study in Pink, and they rent a flat at 221B Baker Street.Several important distinctions about the series needs to be noted. Unlike the stories by Doyle, we are shown what Holmes is thinking and his analytical process. Watson isn't the bumbling acquaintance, but an important part in Holmes' life and in helping solve the mysteries. In at least one instance, Watson saves Holmes' life, the revelation of which could means that Watson would face a murder charge.The police inspector is sharp, but dependent upon Holmes to help him solve difficult cases. Sometimes, Holmes own personal case puts the inspector's on the back burner, but that's okay. To reveal more would be spoil the nature of the story (and I won't tell you which episode this happens in, either.The series stories all develop the arch-enemy to one degree or another. There are, naturally, some red herrings along the way, but that just adds to the entertainment value. The real key is that by the time the case is solved, we know what Holmes knows and that is refreshing from the typical Conan Doyle approach of not revealing anything to the reader (on in the case of many of the older movies, the viewer) until Holmes relates how he solves the case. But in this series, we know what is going on and are not left in the dark. What is fantastic about this one is that if Holmes is stumped, we are stumped. If he is on to something, we are on to something. It really is masterfully written and a lot of fun to watch.The first two stories are absolutely delicious and I was enthralled with how well written and executed they were. Sadly, the last episode was not nearly as good as the first two, which knocked the series as a whole down one star to four. Had the last episode been as sharply written (the performances are always top-notch, so it was the story that suffered) I wouldn't have hesitated giving this series five stars.The pilot (also A Study in Pink) should be watched first, mostly because the techniques used to produce the series change slightly for the series. I'm not sure which I actually preferred, as the plot line remains the same, but the execution of the story itself is different.Now, if only the BBC will continue to produce more of these outstanding Sherlock episodes.

reviewText: Sherlock is by far one of the most entertaining shows to ever cross television. As an advent fan of Dr Who, I was ecstatic to see two of my favorite writers taking on the project of modernizing London's most famous sleuth, and the results do not disappoint. Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman were a golden pairing as Sherlock and Watson, their performances unmatched by any other duo to take on the roles (yes, that most definitely includes the most recent Robert Downy Jr. and Jude Law). But, at an hour and a half and episode that keeps up the wit and the fun, as much as we'd love to see more, the ultimate experience is just too satisfying to fuss, and it's easily worth the purchase.

And downright scary at times too.To Sherlock Holmes fans, you will be delighted at how well he translates into the 21st century - complete with shooting at the walls and debating about the merits of knowing that the earth revolves around the sun. Watson is a bit different than he is in the original, but it's only an improvement - he is our eyes and our emotions, and he could not possibly be a more perfect character, or played by a more perfect actor, to carry the moral and emotional weight of the series. And Sherlock himself - disturbed, possibly damaged, clearly self-destructive, but utterly charming - is one of the greatest reinventions I have ever seen. In fact, probably the greatest ever.I honestly never thought any TV series could surpass Life on Mars as my favorite. And while we're only three episodes in (because there HAS to be more), I can honestly say that Sherlock is better.

reviewText: Let me begin with a confession: I was not entirely "okay" with the idea of a modern version of one of the most beloved literary characters of all time...until I saw the first episode of Series 3 on whro several weeks ago.Of course, like any rational Sherlockian I immediately purchased Series/Season 1 and waited anxiously for its arrival.There have been by far too many plot summaries, and delightful as they are, they do get tedious and repetitive after a time so instead i'll do a 'Character Portrayal' thing. Starting with The Master—BENEDICT CUMBERBATCH AS SHERLOCK HOLMES: I was quite impressed. He is a brilliant actor; quite handsome in that interesting, original way that—I feel—is nessecary to pull off Sherlock, and he does—pull it off. Brilliantly! His Sherlock is wonderful, a self described "High-Functioning Sociopath" with a rapier-sharp mind and an even faster tongue; the man delivers the famous Sherlock monologues in a rapid, lyrical staccato—VERY fast! He also is quite in touch with the quirks and vices of Sherlock: randomly firing his pistol at the wall because he's bored, plucking despondently at the strings of his violin whenever the mood strikes him, abusing drugs, silently staring blankly into space while he thinks, dashing off in the middle of a sentence with no explanation, not eating for days on end, not sleeping—all of Sherlock's classic habits. I highly commend both Benedict and the writers for bringing Sherlock Holmes to life again in the modern world. Bravo!MARTIN FREEMAN AS DR. JOHN WATSON: An intriguing interpretation. Watson is a war veteran who misses the danger of combat and the thrill of the chase. He is the only man who could possibly be Sherlock's flatmate—simply because no one else could tolerate him. But Watson thrills in the excitement, even if Sherlock sometimes drives him to his breaking point. When they meet, Watson is recovering from an injury—there are a few fun nods to the original stories where Watson never can seem to decide where his wound actually was!—and looking for a flatmate. Martin Freeman is an excellent Watson; his acting is top-notch and his portrayal wonderful. His Watson is both amazed by Sherlock's extraordinary mental powers and at the same time bewildered by Sherlock's lack of common knowledge and social skills. He can't help being frustrated with Sherlock at times, for all the obvious reasons, but Martin Freeman treads the fine line between nagging and extreme tolerance with grace. Wonderful.MRS. HUDSON: Mrs. Hudson has perhaps undergone the greatest change from the original stories, usually a rarely seen character with seemingly no past, future, or family; this Mrs. Hudson is introduced as a woman whose past relationship with Sherlock is that of a former client. He ensured her husband was executed, and so owes him a favor. This Mrs. Hudson is rather spacy, is always popping in and out with a tea tray and despairing at the mess 'her boys' have made. She is less of a landlady and housekeeper and more of a mother-figure for Sherlock and Watson.DETECTIVE INSPECTOR LESTRADE: Classic Lestrade. Basically competent; resents the fact that he needs Sherlock's help, while at the same time admiring him—though he'd die before admitting it. It's interesting to see the relationship between Sherlock and Lestrade; they bicker like two pageant girls most of the time, but it is evident there's something akin to grudging mutual respect between them.MYCROFT HOLMES: Excellent job. Mycroft is the very mysterious elder—and smarter—brother of Sherlock. He practically is the British government, and seems to have a hand in every secret agency you've ever heard of, and no doubt some you haven't. He's a delightfully odd, never-leaves-the-office-but-happy-to-do-the-brainwork type and the sibling rivalry between him and Sherlock is hysterical; they're always trying to outdo one another, while at the same time pretending the other doesn't exist. It's quite funny. The repeated jokes about Mycroft's weight are an amusing throwback to the original stories where Mycroft is quite rotund.MORIARTY: He scares me. He really does. Others have said he yells and carries on too much...but I find him terrifying. It's bone-chilling, and his picture should be in the dictionary under: criminally insane, demented, manipulative, psychopath with serious problems that absolutely no psychiatrist in the world could solve. An absolutely wonderful portrayal of Moriarty for which the actor deserves great applause(though it won't be coming from me, because I'd be too scared to be in the same room with him, even though i'm sure he's a lovely person in real life).All in all a wonderful show that masterfully transports the greatest detective of all time to our time. I am a fan.

reviewText: This short but sweet series is a BBC update of the venerable Sherlock Holmes stories by Arthur Conan Doyle, starting with an adaptation of "A Study in Scarlet" titled "A Study in Pink." The characters and the action are moved from gaslight London to present-day London, and the change in period works very well. The story opens on Watson, recently returned from a tour of duty in Afghanistan, being advised by his doctor to try blogging as a method of easing his malaise. Watson doesn't think blogging is the best solution for his problems. He is right.Introducing Martin Freeman's Watson as the viewpoint character was a smart move, since this Sherlock is very much the Sherlock of the first book, contrary-natured and given to offering the sharp side of his tongue, but so brilliant that the police can't ignore his advice. Far from being a second fiddle, this Watson humanizes Sherlock.That's not to speak ill of Sherlock, far from it. A tall drink of water with a rich, deep voice, Benedict Cumberbatch imbues Sherlock with an appealing pugnacity. Even when the character is being a perfect ass, you still want to keep watching him. That's no small feat.The two of them create a great odd couple chemistry as they solve some pretty heinous crimes, all while dodging the machinations of Sherlock's brother, a sometimes-hostile police department, and the mysterious Moriarty. I hear there's a second series in the works, and I can't wait.

reviewText: I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this terrific updating of Sir Arthur Ignatius Conan Doyle's iconic detective transferred into 21st century London.  Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson's exciting new adventures are witty, puzzling and fast-paced.  Although not yet widely discovered, for me this is by far the best detective show on TVDoyle was a Scottish eye doctor apparently with a lot of spare time.  He wrote to amuse himself and I assume to ward off boredom.  His original names for Holmes and Watson were Sheridan and Ormond.  But renamed Sherlock and Watson, they became the most famous detective duo of all time.  There are many who assume the pair actually operated out of the residence at 221B Baker Street.  Every year, thousands of tourists visit the real address of the fictional detectives' home in London.The BBC series was co-created by Steven Moffat (Doctor Who, Coupling) and Mark Gatiss and stars Benedict Cumberbatch as Holmes and Martin Freeman as his loyal friend Doctor John Watson (who is freshly back from Afghanistan may be somewhat traumatized).  Rupert Graves plays Inspector Lestrade.All the details from Doyle's original stories remain.  Especially the dark and strange psychology of the difficult to love, brilliant and somewhat disturbed Holmes.  In the series, Holmes corrects someone who labels him a psychopath.  He says he's a "high functioning sociopath.There are three superb episodes in Season One: "A Study in Pink," "The Blind Banker" and "The Great Game."

reviewText: I'd like to start by saying that I am a great fan of the original Arthur Conan Doyle stories. I have read nearly all of them, as well as innumerable pastiches about Holmes. And due to the fact that I honor the originals so much, perhaps that is why I was hesitant to view this new series which took the character I love so and transported into the 21st century with cars, cell phones and computers. So I watched the series when it premiered on PBS's Masterpiece Mystery, and honestly I loved it. The three episodes in season one each contain so much mystery, suspense and good humor that it's a pleasure to watch for Holmes fans or fans of mystery T.V alike.Episode #1-A Study in PinkThe first episode in the series features the meeting between Dr. John Watson, recently back from Afghanistan in the war, and Sherlock Holmes, a private, consulting detective. Their first case together is the seemingly unconnected suicides of a number of people. When a forth victim is discovered, the word RACHE by the body, Holmes begins to suspect that their not suicides and that a serial killer is in London.A Study in Pink is perhaps the best episode in the series. It features the best humor in the series as well as some of the very best in suspense. Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman have such a fantastic screen chemistry. Never since Jeremy Brett and the late Edward Hardwhicke have I seen such a fantastic chemistry between the stars. For fans of the original stories, it is evident that this episode is based on Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's "A Study in Scarlet." The changes made to the original story are imperative in updating the story to the 21st Century. On a whole, 5 out of 5 stars for this episode.Episode #2-The Blind BankerStrange spray-painted messages and murder as well as the black-market mix in the season's second episode. Hired by the manager of a bank, Holmes is asked to figure out how an office was broken into when the door was locked from within and not forced open. Holmes' inquires lead him to a teller who was found murdered.Another fantastic episode, one which throws in a bit more elements into the stew than the previous. Nonetheless it is still a suspense filled episode much like the first and keeps up the fun which prominent throughout the whole series. Although not based on any one story, "The Blind Banker" is in part inspired by elements from "The Dancing Men" and "The Valley of Fear." I won't say more for fear of giving away IMPORTANT information. On a whole 4 out of 5 stars.Episode #3-The Great GameSherlock Holmes is being dogged by a madman. People are being strapped to bombs and they'll be blown up if Holmes cannot solve a mystery. Holmes and Watson must bet the clock and solve mystery after mystery and unmask the central force behind the crimes."The Great Game" features more suspense, more thrills and more mystery than the other two episodes do, and along with "A Study in Pink" the two make for the greatest entertainment in the series. 5 out of 5 stars for this episode as well.Recently I read that many Sherlock Holmes purists did not enjoy this series very much. I cannot understand this due to the fact that the characters are kept very much the same as they are in the original stories. I do not like it when significant changes are made to the character, however this series hardly makes any. Holmes and Watson are both presented as intellectual people. Perhaps the thing which annoys Holmes fans is the fact that their favorite stories have been updated into the 21st century. However updating classics is hardly a new concept. Until the late 1930s, all Sherlock Holmes movies featured the detective living in the modern world. It was only when 20th Century Fox produced "The Hound of the Baskervilles" and "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes" did they restore the character to the Victorian era. However the second series of Rathbone/Bruce films made at Universal during the forties was set in the modern day as well, and fans of Sherlock Holmes find Basil Rathbone to be one of the best. On a side note, television adaptations of Agatha Christie's novels "Dead Man's Folly", "Three Act Tragedy" and "Thirteen to Dinner" starring Peter Ustinov updated the stories from the thirties and fifties respectively, to the 1980s. However that's another story.Furthermore, despite the changes made to the stories themselves, they are important changes. The revenge back-story told in "A Study in Scarlet" would not have worked in an updated adaptation. In addition "The Five Orange Pips" is used as inspiration for "The Great Game" HOWEVER, once again its back-story just wouldn't work in the type of adaptation being presented here.I myself am a Holmes purist and I feel as though others are being too critical. There have been far too many not good Sherlock Holmes T.V films made in the past - embrace a good one.For Sherlock Holmes fans, this show is certainly a treat. I highly recommend to all Holmes fans or mystery fans alike. I am highly anticipating the series' second season!
summary: The World has Changed...But Sherlock Holmes is still in it

reviewText: Clever turns, witty dialogue - loved it. I am a big fan of all things Holmes but I don't like change. It took me a while to get used to Brett's over the top portrayal after Rathbone's rather crisp Holmes, but he was so droll and on point how could you not love it! I sat down prepared to completely hate this new take but after an hour - hooked all over again! Cumberbatch's face when he has an ephipany is priceless. His chemistry with Martin Freeman is solid and believable and this show would be worthless without it. Finally a Dr. Watson I can enjoy. The others were dreary.I think that the Holmes from the original stories *is* a diva, *is* rather a spoiled brat, but someone who operates on a far different level the most folks so it's merely very exasperating. He needs a sane and wry Dr Watson to keep him tethered to the real world, grounded in whatever century that world and its sun happen to turn in.I loved the first episode, Study in Pink, but not the Blind Banker. I watched it several times but there were many "and ok yeah but what was that supposed to mean" on my side of the screen. And it's not an Brit/American translation problem, it's a plot thing. Doubtless more erudite people then myself will state it more clearly.The last episode, The Great Game made up for it all. And how. The last 15 minutes had me literally yelling NO WAY! Moriarty saying "I will burn the heart out of you" was just so perfectly evil. He's wonderfully nasty in this series. I can't get enough Mycroft either, isn't he perfect? Too much fun indeed. It's been a long time since anything on TV has involved me that much.I do love how they throw many bits of the stories in where you don't expect it, like "Rache" and the Vermeer painting, really added to the fun for me.You know, sure, it's got holes and flaws (and the best Dr. Watson and Mycroft EVER) but you know what? When you watch anything like this, you have to suspend disbelief for a bit and just have fun. I surely did and I can't ask more then that.Addendum: I just received the DVD and had a Festival of Sherlock. Watched it all from end to end :). The pilot included is a great take on Study in Pink but the 90 minute version is far superior. Still, it's lots of fun. I just love that cabbie! I am assuming I have the full BBC version and not the PBS edits but I am not 100% sure. There's some included material on the Blind Banker especially that I wish hadn't been edited out. "The making of" episodes were enjoyable.I am really glad I bought this DVD! I'm such a big Sherlock Holmes fan and this adaptation is just wonderful.

reviewText: If it weren't for NetFlix, I never would have found this gem! It popped up as a recommendation and I'm SO glad I took the time to watch it.  I'm not keen on the recent Sherlock Holmes movies (RDJ is just so arrogant, and it bleeds into all his characters, something I find takes me out of the watching experience), but this portrayal was far more deep and genuine.  Yes, Holmes is a self-absorbed character, but in Cumberbatch's portrayal, it worked, and not because the actor is a pig (like RDJ).  I found that it likely required far more acting prowess than RDJ (or Johnny Miller on "Elementary") ever bring to the character.There is no better, more loyal, more hilarious, or more soulful Watson than Freeman's.  He's not a sidekick in this version.  I'm so grateful to the creators and writers that Watson is not a stooge or a babysitter.  He's an active member of the team and an excellent foil to Sherlock.The writing is superb; it's not as dark as American crime procedural shows are (a fine relief for this Yank who's more than a little sick of all the gratuitous bloodbaths on TV these days), and instead has to be carried by thoughtful writing and believable acting - "Sherlock" has both.  It's also got some wonderfully comedic one-liners, which lighten the dark scenes without cheapening them.A note to those who haven't watched the series, especially American friends who aren't familiar with this style - this is not like regular US TV series where a season will have 21-26 episodes, 42 minutes a piece.  This is similar to BBC's "Wallander" (another immensely good show!) in that it's a series of 3, 90-minute movies, essentially.  It's easy to get greedy and want far more than 3 episodes per season!

reviewText: Generally I cringe at contemporary adaptations of classics -- witness Demi Moore's drive-by shooting on "The Scarlet Letter" years ago or what can best be described as cinematic cancer in the redux of "Charade" called "The Truth About Charlie."  Just let it alone.  But once awhile, something comes along that renews my hope that maybe as a society we aren't getting better technological while getting stupider culturally.  That something would be "Sherlock."  Sure, it can source material that's been around more than 100 years and made into countless TV shows and movies, but "Sherlock" rises above simply being yet another crass attempt at cashing in on a brand name.  Benedict Cumberbatch's Holmes manages to avoid the histrionics of Jeremy Brett's oft-lauded portrayal, the tweaked-on-coke quirkiness of Robert Downey's, and the gentlemanly cultivation of Basil Rathbone's to create a Holmes that is both unique and authentic at the same time.  No, this isn't the Holmes of the books, but in the same way as Daniel Craig's Bond isn't quite the one you've seen before -- but is -- Cumberbatch manages to keep the essence of the character while allowing him to inhabit a completely different "skin."  Set in the current day, "Sherlock" engages Holmes in plots that echo the original stories while being decidedly modern, and manages to do it satisfyingly.  The production is top-notch:  directing, writing, acting.  And Martin Freeman, as a mensch-y Dr. Watson, matches Cumberbatch in bringing something fresh to a well-liked and well-known character.  Even Andrew Scott's Moriarty, while cribbing a bit too much from Anthony Hopkins' Hannibal Lecter, is a more interesting villain than typically seen these days.  "Sherlock" may in fact be too smart for television; it manages to do more with the Holmes character than the entertaining but vapid Downey film versions of late, and it is consistent in its execution.  I'm eagerly awaiting the third season of this terrific series.

reviewText: Despite the ominous signs of a one-year old unbroadcast pilot and the subsequent three-part series being broadcast in the dog days of Summer where TV channels usually bury their misfires while everyone is still on holiday, Mark Gatiss and Steve Moffat's smart modern day reworking of Sherlock Holmes turns out to be a major treat thanks to clever writing, stylish direction and, most important, great casting. That Sherlock works so well is in no small part due to an engagingly sociopathic Holmes in the shape of a superb Benedict Cumberbatch and a better than usual Martin Freeman's no-nonsense Watson, recently demobbed from service in Afghanistan with a partially psychosomatic war wound. While it's never quite as extraordinarily good as the first episode (the second being the weakest), it puts Guy Ritchie's recent blockbuster to shame in the smarts stakes.Finding clever visual ways to show Holmes' deductive process that occasionally threaten to veer into CSI Baker Street territory, it's remarkably effective at transplanting Holmes to the 20th Century with credibility and ingenuity intact - for example, the watch trick from The Sign of Four is brilliantly adapted to a mobile phone that reveals far too much about its owner for comfort, while, instead of a 7% solution, Sherlock's reliant on nicotine patches when bored - and it's savvy enough about Holmes' stamping ground to show just how the one-way system in central London makes it possible for two people on foot to overtake a taxi in one striking action setpiece. In many ways more stylised than Guy Ritchie's take, with intricately edited montages, superimposed captions and occasional but sparing use of split screens, it never loses sight of the character - this is very much Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes as you suspect he might have been written had Sir Arthur lived and worked today.Moffat's parallel tenure on the revamped Doctor Who does seep through in attempts to make Holmes a more dangerous figure who may just capable of becoming the kind of psychopath he hunts and in the through-line Moriarty backstory, as well as a running gag with various characters assuming Watson is Sherlock's boyfriend. Unfortunately Mark Gatiss' Mycroft - Sherlock's smarter brother - is too arch and League of Gentlemen a figure to quite fit in: he's more late Avengers than Arthur Conan Doyle, and Vinette Robinson's adversarial policewoman seems to be channelling the worst aspects of Billie Piper in her surly latter NuWho episodes. But the worst is saved for the unveiling of Moriarty in the otherwise excellent final episode, The Great Game - it's not quite the descent into tedious camp attention-seeking that Russell Tedious Davies brought to the Master in Dr Who, but the actor's absurd vocal gymnastics undermine some good writing with an attention-seeking disregard for reality that characterised the worst of the Jeremy Brett episodes. Which is a shame, because Cumberbatch is one of the very best screen Holmes ever, able to do so very much with (apparently) so little that it's like watching Einstein vs Graham Norton engaging in a battle of wits. It's something that dearly needs to be remedied for the much-anticipated second season, but it's still not enough to detract from the most enjoyable and believable new Holmes in years. Even at 90 minutes, three episodes is far too few, and a year for the next batch of three to be broadcast is already starting to feel like a very long wait.Along with audio commentaries on the first and third episodes and a documentary on the making of the series, the main extra is the unbroadcast 55-minute pilot episode, and it's a good job it was never broadcast or it might have been dismissed as one of those nice ideas that didn't quite work. Despite sharing the same plot as the first episode, it's visibly underfunded compared to the finished version, but more than the lack of style or the rough technical edges it's never quite as sharp as it could be. Much of the backstory is missing - no Mycroft, no Moriarty lurking in the shadows, while Lestrade willingly calls Sherlock for help rather than being badgered into allowing him on the case - and the show has a somewhat more sedentary feeling with dialogue taking precedence over action and scenes often playing too long yet saying less. The scoring is much clumsier too. But it's also clear that there's gold in the pairing of Cumberbatch and Freeman and in the script even if it may need a bit more digging and polishing, and satisfyingly they've learned from their mistakes in the dry run: there's nothing that's been lost or changed that shouldn't have been, nothing left behind that should have been carried over. There's enough that's good in it to have made it worthwhile on its own terms, but thankfully for once good enough wasn't good enough and they came up with a future classic.One curious side note: for some reason Hungarian gypsy music seems to have become the default mode for Holmes scores these days (though David Arnold recorded his themes long before Hans Zimmer started scoring the Guy Ritchie film). It works rather well here and doesn't have the Ennio Morricone/Maurice Jarre influences nor the odd Irish jig of it's bigger-budget rival, but it's a curious musical choice for one of the most British of detectives.

reviewText: There is a reason this series has a consistant 5 star rating. It is just that good. At first, I didn't know what I would make of the 21st century scene but it was in no way a distraction.  In fact, though I ADORE period pieces, it was such a breath of fresh air to see something so different for once. Now, let's talk Sherlock. Mr. Holmes is played to absolute perfection by Bendedict Cumberbatch. This was my first experience with this talented actor and I was pretty much hooked from his first words. His Sherlock is a genius, of course, witty, observant, slightly neurotic, and yes, an arrogant you-know-what at times. He is always sure of himself and is as cocky in his capabilities as one can get. You would think someone like that would be annoying as heck. I mean, he is nasty and flippant towards his landlady, has zero friends and pretty much ignores John Watson upon their first meeting. And yet...he simply draws you in. It's almost addictive in nature. You are holding your breath waiting for him to speak. And speak he does! Non-stop, fast-paced, without even taking a breath. That is his gift, and he is very proud of it. And then you get the rare moments of silence, when only his eyes speak volumes. It really can't be described properly and I don't dare do it justice. You simply have to see it for yourself.John Watson is played by the uber talented Martin Freeman. He is the exact opposite of Holmes. He is quieter, more down-to-earth and does his best to keep Sherlock in check. It doesn't always work, in fact it rarely does, but watching them onscreen together is magic. They have a wonderful rapport and it just gets progressively better as the series evolves.  It never gets personal (Sherlock won't let anyone get that close) but I love the subtle Are they, or Aren't they clues thrown in throughout. It's not even a major plotline, nor is it of importance but it's still amusing to wonder, even as the characters offer no further insight. Either way, they are a fantastic duo and I applaud the casting choice.The actual mystery plotlines are all very intriguing and entertaining. They are based off some of the actual Sherlock Holmes stories, but are fresh to me since I've never read any of them (though now I simply have to!) Everything is done in a clever, almost over-the-top way that actually never gets old. There are a few surprises and twists and leaves you off on a cliffhanger(of course). The screenplay is fantastic, for Sherlock would not be the way he is without it. My only complaint- Just three episdoes. Granted they are close to two hours each but still... it is just that addictive.

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: Reinventing a popular culture character can be tricky business--what do you keep and what do you jetison to make it work in a different setting? Sherlock Holmes wasn't just a clever lad; he had many of the hallmarks of a sociopath--a brilliant sociopath working on the RIGHT side of the law. Although Arthur Conan Doyle didn't invent the detective genre (Edgar Allen Poe created the first detective to use deductive reasoning--or more accurately inductive reasoning ) but he perfected it assisting in the birth of an entire genre of fiction that has impacted every form of modern entertainment.In Stephen Moffat's ("Doctor Who") reinvention of Arthur Conan Doyle's brilliant, iconoclastic consulting detective Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch) is brought firmly into the 21st century. Like Universal Studios brought Holmes into the modern era before in the 1940's with the films featuring Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce as Holmes and Watson solving crimes during World War II in England. It was a stroke of genius on the part of the studio at the time as it made Holmes relevant once again.Moffat and his collaborators have once again taken the bold step of bringing Holmes into the modern age but also creating a Holmes that is every bit as contemporary as the time he lives in. Holmes meets Afganistan vet Dr. John Watson (Martin Freeman) through a mutual friend and the duo immediately hit it off. In "A Case in Pink" (an adaption of "A Study in Scarlet") Holmes is brought in by DI Lestrade (Rupert Graves) to solve a series of perplexing suicides which turn out to be the work of an unusual serial killer. Holmes must find out how and why this serial killer picks his victims before he kills again.Featuring marvelous performances from Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman as Holmes and Watson, uses the opportunity to reinvent characters that could easily have become nothing more than pale imitations of previous performers from Rathbone to Jeremy Brett who was often considered the actor that most closely embodied Doyle's vision of Holmes. Moffat effortlessly integrates the story of the first meeting between Holmes and Watson into a complex, fascinating murder mystery that puts to shame most procedural shows. In fact as much as I enjoyed the recent theatrical film "Sherlock Holmes" with Robert Downey, Jr., THIS Sherlock is the superior of the two with much more complex and fascinating characters placed within a more complex interesting story that effectively takes elements from Doyle's own stories.Visually dazzling featuring top notch direction "Sherlock" takes an unusual approach to Holmes and how his mind works as well--we SEE the words that occur to Holmes as he is examining evidence. While this might shound awkward it works brilliantly allowing the scene to proceed without unnecessary exposition dialog that might slow down the action. It's a gimmick that always works because it reflects Holmes attempting to solve the case giving the technique context."Sherlock" looks quite nice with plenty of detail, a sharp, nice looking high def transfer. The only flaw that I can see are problems with aliasing in all three episodes. I also noticed that facial detail isn't quite as strong as a contemporary high def transfer but that could be due to the use of DNR to allow for a lower bit rate. "Sherlock" may not look perfect but the series still looks quite good.Audio puts dialog front and center but the 5.1 mix leaves a bit to be desired; while it is nicely done the mix isn't quite as immersively as I would expect for a recent program like "Sherlock". I could be wrong on that count of course--it simply could be choice on the part of the producers to have the sound like this. Either way, "Sherlock" looks and sounds quite good even if it isn't a demo quality presentation.We get a commentary track on "A Case in Pink" and on the third episode of the series. In the case of "Pink" we get the writer/producers and in the case of "The Great Game" the third episode we get to listen to our two leads Cumberbatch and Freeman where they discuss working on the series, their approach to the characters, etc.We also get a featurette on the second disc entitled "Unlocking Sherlock" which covers the creation of the series and the first unaired pilot for the series. For the Blu-ray (I don't know about the DVD) we also get an earlier unaired version of the pilot film."Sherlock" is an exceptional series and I'm hoping that the BBC commissions a second season for the series with three more 90 minute TV movies. The leads are appealing and bring a unique interpretation to their roles and Moffat and his writers do a terrific job of crafting a trio of top notch and entertaining TV movies.
summary: No deduction necessary--"Sherlock" is a masterful reinvention of Doyle's stories

reviewText: One must wonder why British television seasons are so short; this first set consists of all of three episodes. A terrific updating of the Sherlock Holmes tales sets the characters in the contemporary era, in a London filled with social media, cars, and the fast pace of life. It's a testament to the writing and casting that they fit so very well into current society. Benedict Cumberbatch is ideally cast as Holmes, playing him as brilliant but deranged, and oblivious to so much around him regardless. There's a deviousness in his take on the character that perfectly fits in with Sherlock. Martin Freeman is a well cast Watson, a former Army doctor brought into Holmes' orbit. He gives the role a complexity that suits it, as he tries to keep up with his counterpart. As with previous Watsons, Freeman is a good foil to Cumberbatch as Holmes. The two leads have a great rapport, and it makes the three episodes flow together nicely. Rupert Graves turns up as a contemporary inspector Lestrade, bothered by the fact that he must occasionally call in Holmes for help. Mark Gatiss, the show co-creator, turns up as Holmes' brother Mycroft, running British intelligence. And we even get a Moriarty in the shadows for good measure. A pleasure to watch, though you might want to use subtitles on this. Holmes tends to talk quickly.

I've seen every episode and can't wait to watch this on BD when it comes out in November.  The transition from the foggy streets of late Victorian London to present day is as smooth as it can be.  Don't be fooled!  Get this show!Entertaining from start to finish, Sherlock is a top-notch program from BBC that I believe will get better and better as time goes on.  I hope they realize what they have and keep it going for a long time.  Holmes and Watson are played by brilliant actors who understand the iconic characters they are playing but also are skilled enough to give their portrayels a different slant we haven't seen before.  I hope to watch them grow in the role for many years.

reviewText: I was dead-set against this when I first heard about it.  I love Doyle's Sherlock Holmes, and have read through The Canon many times.  I love Jeremy Brett'sSherlock Holmesand hatedRobert Downey Jr's.  Holmes should not be hip.  Holmes should not be updated, and Holmes should never say "Elementary, my Dear Watson."After much opposition, "Sherlock" was finally shoved into my hands as a Christmas Present and I was told to "just watch it."  And I did.  And it was very, very good.Right off the bat, I was sold by Martin Freeman's Dr. John Watson.  Having him come home wounded from the current Afghanistan war was brilliant, and his entire manner was just right.  This was a strong, competent Dr. Watson, the kind of guy who backed up Holmes with a revolver in his pocket.  I was less overwhelmed by Benedict Cumberbatch's Sherlock.  He didn't look right, with that mopish hair, and his introduction of having him whip a corpse to test for bruising patterns was too sensationalist.  But he grew on me, and I eventually accepted him in the role.Even with the series being updated, there are lots of scavenger hunt nods in the series for those who known their Canon.  Watson's psychosomatic limp coming from a wound to the shoulder was an excellent reference to the traveling injury in Doyle's stories.  And all the homosexual misunderstandings between Holmes and Watson made me laugh, that being a common thread for Holmes interpreters and played upon inThe Private Life of Sherlock Holmes.  In the second episode, "The Blind Banker," there is a nice modernization of the five orange pips from "The Sign of Four," and "A Study in Pink" is a nice updating of "A Study in Scarlet."If there was a disappointment, it was in Moriatry.  The grand reveal of the character was well done, but Andrew Scott played him as a cackling psycho rather than a cold and calculating reflection of Holmes.  He has more in common with The Joker than with traditional plays on Holmes's arch-enemy.  I also would have liked to have seen Watson's medical expertise being brought into play.  More than once Watson defers to Holmes on medical issues, which just didn't ring true.Also, be warned; the box set says "Season One," and this is true.  This is the complete first season.  But, the first season consists only of three episodes, and hardly even justifies being on two disks.  On top of that, it ends on a cliff-hanger.  So this is more of a teaser than a satisfying viewing experience.  There is enough here to make you want more, but then you have to sit and wait while that "more" is filmed.
